case_name: Sunil Kumar Paul v. The State

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Paul was a clerk in the office of the Sub-Divisional Health Officer at Barrackpore in 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a clerk in the office of the Sub-Divi- sional Health Officer at Barrackpore in 1955-56. He used to prepare bills of the establishment, to present them at the ,Sub-treasury and later present them at the State Bank at Barrackpore, to receive payment in cash and to make over that amount to the Sub-Divisional Health Officer.

facts.text: Appellant used to prepare bills, present them at Sub-treasury and State Bank at Barrackpore, receive cash and hand over to Sub-Divisional Health Officer.

anchor.surface_text: He used to prepare bills of the establishment, to present them at the ,Sub-treasury and later present them at the State Bank at Barrackpore, to receive payment in cash and to make over that amount to the Sub-Divisional Health Officer.

facts.text: On October 5, 1956, appellant presented a bill for Rs. 1,769 of which Rs. 5-10-0 to Postal Life Insurance Ledger and balance Rs. 1,763-6-0 in cash.

anchor.surface_text: On October 5, 1956, the appellant presented a bill for Rs. 1,769 out of Which a sum of Rs. 5-10-0 was to be credited in the Postal Life Insurance Ledger and the balance of Rs. 1,763-6-0 was to be received in cash.

facts.text: The bill was passed by Sub-Treasury and presented to Bank on October 6, 1956 for Rs. 1,763-6-0 cash, paid to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: This bill was duly passed by the Sub-Treasury and was subsequently presented to the Bank on October, 6, 1956 for payment of Rs. 1,763-6-0. The Bank paid this amount to the appellant.

facts.text: The amount was not paid to the Sub-Divisional Health Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank paid this amount to the appellant. The amount was number paid to the Sub-Divisional Health Officer.

facts.text: No records in office referred to such bill being prepared and submitted.

anchor.surface_text: The amount was number paid to the Sub-Divisional Health Officer. In fact, the records of the Office of the Sub-Divisional Health Officer did number refer to any such bill being prepared and submitted to the Sub-Treasury and the Bank for payment.

facts.text: A bill for practically the same items was presented on October 1, 1956 for Rs. 1,767, Rs. 5-10-0 to PLI, balance Rs. 1,761-6-0 cash, received and handed over to officer.

anchor.surface_text: A bill for practically the same items which were mentioned in the bill cashed on October 6, was however presented on October 1, 1956. It was for an amount of Rs. 1,767 out of which Rs. 5-10-0 were to be credited to the PLI account ledger and the balance of Rs. 1,761-6-0 were to be paid in cash.

facts.text: The October 1 bill was initially for Rs. 1,769 but corrected to reduce by Rs. 2 before encashment.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of this bill was received on October 1, and was duly handed over to the Sub-Divisional Health Officer. It may be mentioned that this bill. cashed on October 1, 1956 was at first prepared for Rs. 1,769 and the amount to be received in cash was to be Rs. 1,763-6-0 but prior to this encashment, a companyrection was made at some stage, and the bill was reduced by Rs. 2 in the total amount and companysequently in the amount to be paid in cash.

facts.text: Presentation of bill on Oct 6 came to notice of Sub-Divisional Health Officer via Accountant General; enquiry found no such bill or receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The fact of the presentation of a bill for its encashment of Rs. 1,763-6-0 on October 6, 1956 came to the numberice of the. Sub.-Divisional Health Officer at the instance of the Accountant General and on enquiry it was found that numbersuch bill had been actually presented by his office for encashment and that numbersuch amount was received by him.

facts.text: This led to complaint, enquiries, investigation, prosecution of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: This led to a companyplaint and further enquiries and investigation which ended in the prosecution of the appellant.

facts.text: Case made over to Special Judge under West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment (Special Courts) Act, 1949 as offence under s.409 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The case was made over to the Special Judge by the Government in view of the provisions of the West Bengal Criminal Law Amendment  Special Courts  Act, 1949  W. B. Act XXI of 1949 , hereinafter called the Act, as it involved an offence punishable under s. 409 I.P.C.

facts.text: Special Judge tried, convicted appellant under s.409 IPC, sentenced to 2 years RI and fine Rs.2000.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge tried the appellant for that offence and companyvicted him and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for two years and to pay a fine of Rs. 2,000.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 745 of 1959, judgment June 15, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 15, 1961, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 745 of 1959.

facts.text: High Court agreed no s.409 IPC, but held proved s.420 IPC for cheating State Bank employees by false bill representation, altered conviction to s.420, 1 year RI + Rs.2000 fine.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the appellants companytenion that numberoffence under s. 409 I.P.C. had been made out, but held.that he was proved to have companymitted an offence under s. 420 I.P.C. It accordingly altered his companyviction from an offence under s. 409 I.P.C. to one under s. 420 I.P.C., for cheating the employees of the State Bank, Barrackpore, by representing that the bill for Rs. 1,769 gross and Rs. 1.763-6-0 cash drawn on October 6, 1956, was a genuine bill drawn by the Sub-Divisional Health Officer, and thereby dishonestly inducing the Banks staff to make over the sum of Rs. 1,763-6-0 to him and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for one year and to fine of Rs. 2,000.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court: Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1961, with certificate from Calcutta HC under Art.134(1)c.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 156 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 15, 1961, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 745 of 1959. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant. K. Chakraborty and P. K. Bose, for the respondent. March 6, 1964.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered March 6, 1964 by Raghubar Dayal J.

anchor.surface_text: March 6, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-Sunil Kumar Paul has preferred this appeal, after obtaining a certificate from the Calcutta High Court under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Facts found by High Court sufficient to justify s.420 IPC offence.

anchor.surface_text: The facts found by the High Court are sufficient to justify the finding that the appellant companymitted the offence under s. 420 I.P.C.

facts.text: Appellant is a public servant, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the appellant is a public servant. This has number been disputed.

facts.text: Appellant presented false bill purporting to act as clerk authorized to cash bills.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did present the false bill purporting to present it in the discharge of his duties as a clerk of the Office of the Sub-Divisional Health Officer who was duly authorised to present bills and cash them.

facts.text: Charge-sheet by Investigating Officer stated appellant dishonestly drew Rs.1,763-6-0 by submitting false duplicate Estt. Pay Bill on Oct 6, 1956, not credited to office.

anchor.surface_text: This charge-sheet narrates in the companyumn meant for the name of offences and circumstances companynected with it that on the 6th October 1956 Sunil Kumar Paul, a Public servant in the employment of the office of the Sub-Divisional Health Officer, Barrackpore i.e.,  clerk  dishonestly drew Rs. 1,763-6-0 excluding Postal Life Insurance deduction of Rs. 5-10-0 from the State Bank of India, Barrackpore Branch by submitting a false duplicate Estt. Pay Bill for the office of the said S.D.H.O., Barrackpore. The money drawn was number credited to the office of the Sub-Divisional Health Officer, Barrackpore.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Special Court competent to try s.420 IPC, upholds High Court alteration of conviction.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Special Court companyld try the appellant for the offence under s. 420 I.P.C. and that therefore the High Court was right in altering his companyviction from that under s. 409 to s. 420 I.P.C.

facts.text: Sentence of 1 year RI and Rs.2000 fine not severe.

anchor.surface_text: The last companytention for the appellant was that the sentence is severe. We do number companysider a sentence of 1 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 2,000 severe.
under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the Special Court could try the appellant for the offence under s. 420 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government was therefore competent to allot the case involving that offence to the Special Court. In fact it had to allot the case to the Special Court in view of the provision of sub-s. (1) of s. 4 to the effect that the offences specified in the Schedule shall be triable by Special Courts only. The question therefore really is whether the Special Court could try the appellant for the offence under s. 420 I.P.C.

issues.text: Whether presentation of a false bill by the appellant constituted committing the offence while purporting to act as such public servant

anchor.surface_text: An offence under s. 420 P.C. when committed in certain circumstances is also mentioned in the Schedule. It has to be tried by Special Courts only when it is committed by a public servant while purporting to act as such. There is no doubt that the appellant is a public servant. This has not been disputed.

issues.text: Whether the Special Court could take recourse to the provisions of s. 237 Cr. P.C. and whether the requirements of s. 237 Cr. P.C. were satisfied

anchor.surface_text: The Special Court could not take recourse to the provisions of s. 237 Cr. P.C., and if it could, the requirements of s. 237 Cr. P.C. were not satisfied in the present case, and consequently the High Court could not have altered the conviction of the appellant from an offence under s. 409 I.P.C. to one under s. 420.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s. 236 Cr. P.C. apply only where there is doubt about the facts which can be proved post-evidence

anchor.surface_text: It is urged for the appellant that the provisions of s. 236 Cr. P. C. would apply only to those cases where there be no doubt about the facts which can be proved and a doubt arises as to which of the several offences had been committed on the proved facts.

issues.text: Whether under the proviso to s. 4 of the Act, the Special Court can try any other offence only when the accused is specifically charged with that offence

anchor.surface_text: It is then urged for the appellant that under the proviso to s. 4 of the Act, the Special Court can try any other offence only when the accused is specifically charged with that offence. The language of the proviso does not lead to such a conclusion.

issues.text: Whether the ingredients of an offence under s. 420 I.P.C. were alleged and proved by the prosecution and whether the accused was prejudiced due to absence of charge under s.420, curable by s.537 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The ingredients of an offence under s. 420 I.P.C. were neither alleged nor proved by the prosecution. The accused has been prejudiced on account of the absence of the necessary allegations and the omission to frame a charge for an offence under s.420 I.P.C. and therefore the provisions of s. 537 Cr. P. C. would not cure this defect in trial.

arguments.claim: A case involving an offence under s. 420 IPC cannot be allotted for trial to a Special Court unless committed by a public servant while purporting to act as such

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has, urged the following points A case involving an offence under s. 420 P.C. cannot be allotted for trial to a Special Court by the State Government when such an offence is number companymitted by a public servant while purporting to act as such public servant.

arguments.claim: The expression 'while purporting to act as such public servant' means while purporting to act in discharge of official duties; false bill presentation not discharge of duty

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant, Mr. Mukherjee, has urged that the expression while purporting to act as such public servant be construed to mean while purporting to act in the discharge of official duties and that presentation of a false bill could number be in the discharge of official duty.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: would be companymitted by him as a public servant purporting to act as such, and that a case involving this offence also companyld have been allotted

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction: purporting to present in discharge of duties, appellant presented as authorized clerk

P.C. were number satisfied in the present case, and that companysequently the High Court could number have altered the companyviction of the appellant from an offence under s. 409 I.P.C. to one under s. 420.

arguments.claim: s.236 CrPC applies only where no doubt about facts but doubt on offence post-evidence

anchor.surface_text: It is urged for the appellant that the provisions of s. 236 Cr. P. C. would.apply only to those cases where there be numberdoubt about the facts which can be proved and a doubt rises as to which of the several offences had been companymitted on the proved facts.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in the charge-sheet or an offence under s. 420 I.P.C. When a charge under s. 420 I.P.C. companyld have been framed by the trial Court by virtue of s.

arguments.claim: Under proviso to s.4 Act, Special Court can try other offence only if specifically charged

anchor.surface_text: It is then urged for the appellant that under the proviso to s. 4 of the Act, the Special Court can try any other offence only when the accused is specifically charged with that offence.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso allows trial if chargeable under CrPC at same trial; does not require framed charge, s.237 allows conviction without

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.4 only for offences related to scheduled offence; s.420 ingredients different from s.409

anchor.surface_text: It has also been urged for the appellant that the proviso to s. 4 does number give any power to the Special Court to try an offence which be independent of the offence mentioned in the allotment order. That is to say, the Special Court, in this case, could have tried the appellant only for such offences which will be in some way related to the offence under s. 409 I.P.C. It is further urged that the ingredients of the offence under s. 420 I.P.C. are absolutely different from the ingredients of the offence under s. 409 I.P.C.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso refers to any offence chargeable under CrPC; no additional limitations beyond CrPC

arguments.court_reasoning: 1 year RI and Rs.2000 fine not severe

arguments.claim: Bhajahar Mondal case supports that case allotted for s.409 cannot be tried for s.420

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed on the case reported as Bhajahar Mondal The State or West Bengal 1  in support of the contention that the appellant should number have been tried by the Special Court of the offence under s. 420 I.P.C. when the case was allotted as one involving an offence under s. 409 I.P.C.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: which the accused may be charged at the same trial in accordance with the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The accused companyld be char

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts different: allotment for non-existent offence; here s.409 existed and scheduled

arguments.claim: Nanak Chand supports s.236 only where doubt on offence from proved facts

anchor.surface_text: In support of his contentions, learned counsel for the appellant referred to the case reported as Nanak Chand v. The State of Punjab.  1  wherein it was stated at p. 1212 The provisions of section 236 can apply only in cases where there is numberdoubt about the facts which can be proved but a doubt arises as to which of several offences have been companymitted on the proved facts

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure were to affect the nature of the offence which companyld be tried by the Special Court. We are theref

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: no doubt on facts constituting only one offence (murder); here allegations allow doubt

arguments.claim: Facts proved constitute s.420 IPC offence

anchor.surface_text: The facts found by the High Court are sufficient to justify the finding that the appellant committed the offence under s. 420 I.P.C.

arguments.claim: Appellant committed s.420 while purporting to act as public servant, so within Schedule

anchor.surface_text: On the facts proved, it is number to be doubted that the appellant presented the bill for Rs. 1,763-6-0 at the State Bank oil October 6, purporting to act as the clerk of the Sub-Divisional Health Officer. The bill presented was on be half of that officer.

arguments.claim: Charge-sheet allegations create doubt under s.236 CrPC allowing charge for s.420

anchor.surface_text: This charge-sheet narrates in the column meant for the name of offences and circumstances connected with it that on the 6th October 1956 Sunil Kumar Paul, a Public servant... dishonestly drew Rs. 1,763-6-0... by submitting a false duplicate Estt. Pay Bill...

arguments.claim: Proviso s.4(1) and s.5(2) Act allow CrPC including s.236/237 to apply to Special Court

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the consideration that the offence of cheating... fell within the offences mentioned in the Schedule, the appellant could be tried by the Special Court for this offence in view of the proviso to s. 4... Section 5 2  of the Act provides that the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure so far as they are number incon- sistent with the Act, would apply...

arguments.claim: No prejudice to accused; charge-sheet sufficient for s.420 misrepresentation

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the statement in the charge-sheet that the appellant presented a false bill to the State Bank and cashed it. This allegation is sufficient for the pur- pose of the offence under s. 420 I.P.C.... the presentation of the bill for encashment carries with it the representation that it is a genuine bill...

arguments.claim: Special Court could try s.420; HC right to alter conviction

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Special Court could try the appellant for the offence under s. 420 I.P.C. and that therefore the High Court was right in altering his conviction from that under s. 409 to s. 420 I.P.C.

holdings.text: The Special Court could try the appellant for the offence under s. 420 I.P.C. and the High Court was right in altering his conviction from s. 409 to s. 420 I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the Special Court could try the appellant for the offence under s. 420 I.P.C. and that therefore the High Court was right in altering his conviction from that under s. 409 to s. 420 I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case allotted for scheduled offence s.409 IPC; s.420 also scheduled when by public servant purporting to act as such (facts show presentation as authorised clerk); alternatively, proviso s.4(1) + ss.236/237 CrPC allow charging/convicting alternative offence based on charge-sheet facts alleging false bill dishonest drawing.

holdings.text: The appellant committed the s.420 IPC offence while purporting to act as a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts proved, it is not to be doubted that the appellant presented the bill for Rs. 1,763-6-0 at the State Bank on October 6, purporting to act as the clerk of the Sub-Divisional Health Officer. The bill presented was on be half of that officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant public servant (undisputed); presented false bill as clerk authorised to present/cash bills on behalf of officer, thus purporting to act in discharge of duties even though bill false.

holdings.text: Provisions of ss.236/237 CrPC apply pre-trial based on prosecution allegations in charge-sheet creating doubt as to which offence facts constitute, allowing charge/conviction for alternative offence.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 236 and 237 read If a single act or series of acts is of such a nature that it is doubtful which of several offences the facts which can be proved will constitute, the accused may be charged...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Framing charge under s.236 earlier than proof stage; court considers possible offences from complaint/charge-sheet allegations (here false duplicate bill dishonest drawing); s.237 allows conviction of different chargeable offence; distinguished Nanak Chand (no doubt on facts/sole offence).

holdings.text: Proviso to s.4(1) of the Act allows Special Court to try other offences chargeable under CrPC at same trial without requiring specific charge framed.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the consideration that the offence of cheating... fell within the offences mentioned in the Schedule, the appellant could be tried by the Special Court for this offence in view of the proviso to s. 4...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso text: 'may also try any offence other than... with which the accused may under the Code... be charged at the same trial'; s.5(2) applies CrPC unless inconsistent; no requirement for framed charge, s.237 allows conviction without.

holdings.text: Charge-sheet allegations sufficient for s.420 IPC ingredients; no prejudice from no s.420 charge as s.237 applies.

anchor.surface_text: This charge-sheet narrates... that on the 6th October 1956 Sunil Kumar Paul... dishonestly drew Rs. 1,763-6-0... by submitting a false duplicate Estt. Pay Bill...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge-sheet states dishonest drawing via false bill submission (representation of genuineness implicit in presentation); proved by facts; s.537 irrelevant as s.237 cures; no need to prove appellant prepared bill.

holdings.text: At trial for s.409 IPC, appellant could have been charged with s.420 IPC under s.236 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that at the trial of the appellant for an offence under s. 409 I.P.C., in this case, the appellant could have also been charged for an offence under s. 420 I. C. in view of s. 236 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge-sheet facts (false bill, dishonest drawing from bank) create doubt whether s.409 or s.420; s.236 allows alternative charge pre-proof.

holdings.text: Sentence of 1 year RI and Rs.2000 fine is not severe.

anchor.surface_text: The last contention for the appellant was that the sentence is severe. We do not consider a sentence of 1 years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 2,000 severe.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amount embezzled Rs.1763; reduced from 2 years; proportionate.

holdings.text: Bhajahar Mondal distinguished: allotment here for existing scheduled offence s.409 unlike non-existent s.165A there.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of that case were very different. The order allotting the case mentioned the offence... under s. 161 read with s. 116 P.C.... An offence under s. 165A was not mentioned in the Schedule...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different facts: bad allotment for non-scheduled/non-existent offence vs. here valid for s.409.

precedents.citation: Bhajahar Mondal The State or West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed on the case reported as Bhajahar Mondal The State or West Bengal 1  in support of the contention that the appellant should not have been tried by the Special Court of the offence under s. 420 I.P.C. when the case was allotted as one involving an offence under s. 409 I.P.C.

precedents.case_name: Bhajahar Mondal v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: A case allotted to Special Court for offence under s.161/116 IPC cannot be tried for non-existent offence under s.165A IPC not in Schedule
Sections 236 and 237 CrPC allow conviction for an offence not charged if evidence establishes it and it could have been charged under s.236
precedents.cited_holding: A man may be convicted of an offence, although there has been no charge in respect of it, if the evidence is such as to establish a charge that might have been made.

precedents.citation: Ramaswamy Nadar v. The State of Madras 2
precedents.case_name: Ramaswamy Nadar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court can convict for different offence under ss.236/237 CrPC even if accused acquitted of charged offence
precedents.cited_holding: High Court could convict under s.403 when charged under s.420

precedents.citation: the State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kandimalla Subbaiah 3
precedents.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Kandimalla Subbaiah
precedents.cited_proposition: Special Judge trying scheduled offence can try other offences chargeable at same trial under CrPC
precedents.cited_holding: Special Judge under CLA 1952 can try offences like s.120B r/w 466,467,420 IPC along with Corruption Act offence

precedents.citation: Nanak Chand v. The State of Punjab. 1
precedents.case_name: Nanak Chand v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: s.236 CrPC applies only where doubt as to which of several offences committed on proved facts
precedents.cited_holding: No doubt about facts constituting murder, so s.236 inapplicable
